Lol, this isn't right... The banking system does not loan out depositors money, banks create brand new money (bank credit) when making a loan by way of double entry bookkeeping (they create a $10m loan asset and a $10m demand deposit liability). The amount of new money they can create is constrained by fractional reserve requirements set out by law and regulation (often 9:1). This means banks have a real incentive to acquire more depositors, but it doesn't mean they loan out depositors' money! To put it simply for people, if the banking system has $10 worth of deposits, it can make $90 of new loans. If they're lending out their depositors money, where does the other $80 come from??? Answer: nowhere - they don't loan out depositors money - they create new money!

It is pathetic that in a video showing how banking works you have deliberately left out the money creation bit

Banks are not financial intermediaries. Banks create money by selling their credit in exchange for cash or debt. Banks create credit out of nothing unlike non bank financial institutions. Banks create deposits when they exchange their credit for cash or debt(making loans). The reason why banks pay interest for cash is for liquidity purposes. Cash or tokens provide liquidity in an economy by being able to exchanged for goods or services. But demand deposits can be accessed by debit or credit cards, letters of credit, bank transfers, drafts, cheques, bills of exchange, bills of credit. These cash substitutes can be used as substitute for cash. When customers demand for cash and the banks cash runs out, the deposits in the bank never run out. The cause of bank runs is not being able to provide liquidity. After all only about 3% of all money is in cash. Today most people use credit/debit cards and other electronic payment methods and therefore bank runs almost never happens. This is coupled by the fact that central banks can print as much cash as necessary for tokens today unlike before when coins were made up of copper, silver or gold.

Taking the savings of some people for small interest and lending it to other people for higher interest is exactly how banking DOESN'T work. If this would be true people had to be forced to save money, but in real life the amount of saver's money stored by banks is tiny compared to the amounts of credit money granted by banks. So, where does the money come from? Answer: money is issued by the central bank of a country (or, in case of the Euro zone: by the European Central Bank). But the central bank doesn't simply "print" the money and scatter it all over the country. Instead, the money is pulled by the creation of value. A customer who raises a bank credit receives fresh central bank money. The bank just borrows the money for the credit from the central bank for a low interest rate and then lends it to the customer to a higher interest rate. The customer literaly have to earn the money for each loan instalment by creating value, that means: doing work.

I don't consider renting passive income unless you have professional property management. Most people who rent don't count their time and effort needed just to make a tiny return on their massive investment. For example, you invest $599,000 to buy a second home and rent it out for $3000 a month. Let assume you are cash flow positive on the property and you make $1000 a month or $12,000 a year. What would your annualized return be? 2 percent on the entire amount. Now, you can argue that your return is much higher since you only put down $120,000 on the property. However, you are on the hook for the full $600k regardless of what the future FMV of the house is. Furthermore, people assume that their home will always appreciate in value however, this is a false assumption you can make. In the best case, you will gain some capital appreciation thanks to the central bank increasing the money supply, however, if inflation heats up, you can see your property actually start to lose money in real terms.  This is because there is an inverse relationship between housing and nominal interest rates. The central bank will attempt to slow down inflation with higher interest rates and curb lending. This video needs to be taken down, and updated. The description of how banks work and operate are not truthful or factful. Once upon a time, way back, the description could have been correct. Nowadays, banks lend money they never had to third parties, and take interest rates from the lenders, even though the banks never had the cash in the first place.

Instead, the central banks generate/create new money in the system ad hoc, on request from a private bank whenever the private bank wants to lend something to someone. This means that the total amount of currency in the system increases every time someone takes a loan from the bank, increasing inflation. The system is sick, and Kurtzgesagt need to update their data.

First of all, the italian word for bench is “panca”, with the “P” not the “B”, and has nothing to do with banks. The exchange of money taking place on benches simply isn’t a thing, I don’t know what your sources are 😂 The word “banca” comes from “Banco” (with the “B” this time), that means “table” in English. It was referred to the tables on the streets where this exchanges took really place, separating the vendor from the buyer. So Banca comes from Banco.

This is literally wrong.

When a bank lends you money it simply increases the amount in your bank account. In return it has a contract from you to pay off that loan according to a certain schedule.
The deposit in your account is new money. It is not transferred from anywhere else. Banks do not lend out anybody's money.
(Has a loan to a credit-worthy customer ever been denied because the bank didn't have the funds? No.)

Each loan is a new creation of 'bank money'. At first it is simply numbers in a ledger. The bank's obligation is to issue you with national currency on demand, which in effect is a conversion of the bank money in your account to government money (national currency).

A good presentation except one gross error: Banks Create Fake Money (credit-money) When They Make A Loan.
This is called "Fractional Reserve" banking (with "reserve" meaning whatever they want it to mean).
The Cult of Cthulhu brought me here.

This regurgitation of the idea that banks lend unused savings deposits to people to make money is simply wrong. That is not at all how banking (or money and debt - they are actually the same thing) works. Google 'fractional reserve lending' and 'modern money mechanics' (it's a book) to find out how these things ACTUALLY work.

Seriously? Such a slick well-produced video just to parrot the falsehood of the "loanable funds" theory of money? Banks do NOT lend out savers' deposits, that hasn't been the case since money was mostly gold coins. Banks CREATE deposits when they lend, and that process is not dependent on savers at all except as a measure in banks' capital requirements. So terrible, savings deposits are NOT revenue, deposits are a LIABILITY of the bank for which they pay interest to depositors. They're stating the reality backwards.

In all the video is well-meaning, but spreading misinformation about how banking actually works.

The banking system can be improved. It has fatal flaws that help banking executives make billions while damaging the economy with hyper inflation.
The reason inflation exists is that banks give more credit than they are supposed to and each time there's not enough money, they take money from the central bank to pay their debt, which prints money basically.
If banks however lend only 50% of the money they have in vault, only to a specific group of people who are startups or small business owners with long term based contracts and with payable interest rates, then the world would still continue to develop, there would also be no inflation thus no economical crysis. We are all in this game whether we want to play it or not. I am not participating in this system, not taking a loan and only using my credit card to buy stuff online and always paying the credit card with full amount before my receipt arrives. Furthermore, banks don't necessarily lend the money of their customers. They partially create the money for credits out of thin air. It is a difference which matters whether a credit is REfinanced by an own customer, by credit of another bank (directly, or indirectly by swapping customers with another bank) or ultimately by credit of a central bank.

Why does everyone think this is so complicated? It's pretty damn simple at the base level. Banks provide individuals a safe place to deposit their money, then the banks take that deposit money and invest it on things like mortgages, student loans, car loans, credit cards, etc.

The more the banks lend, the riskier it is, but the potential reward is also much larger. The recession in 2008 happened because banks (especially in the US) were taking people's deposit money and investing it in risky investments like stock market investments and very cheap mortgages aka subprime mortgages (hence the "subprime mortgage crisis")
Once a lot of people were unable to continue making their mortgage payments, the banks that gave out these subprime mortgages went out of business, meaning all the money that individuals had deposited in these same banks was gone.

Banks HAVE to collect money so they can lend, but they still end up creating money. I usually explain it this way: Imagine john. John has all the money there is in the economy - 1000$. he puts it in a bank. The bank by law has to reserve 10%. So the bank reserves 100$ and lends out the other 900$ to Charles. Charles then takes this loan and puts it in another bank. That bank reserves 10% (90$) and lends the other 810$ to Nick. Now you can see how money has been created. Charles has 900$ to spent and nick has 810$ to spend (to a total of 1710$), while there is only 1000$ real dollars in this economy. If Charles or Nick fails to pay, the system crumbles. However, each bank lent out less than what they received in deposits. Conlusion:  Yes, banks create money. No, they cant do it arbitrarly.

No. Banks are not intermediaries. It's double-entry book-keeping. When a bank makes a loan it adds an entry to the ledger in the assets column, which is the amount of money that the customer owes the bank. And it makes a corresponding entry in the liabilities column, which is the amount it owes the customer (the deposit). ie. loans create deposits. Not the other way round.

Banks lend by crediting accounts. They issue their own deposit liabilities. Banks use central bank reserves to settle transactions on behalf of depositors. Banks net transactions we make against each other to minimize the need for reserves. Banks then lend any excess reserves/surplus reserves (not every country has reserve requirements) to each other. This redistributes reserves so that 1 dollar of reserves can be used to settle many dollars over and over again.

Bank deposits are liabilities of the issuing bank. When depositors deposit cash they receive a claim on a bank that can be either redeemed for cash or used to make a payment with a check or credit card.

Bank loan example

Bank:
Assets
+100 loan

Liabilities
+100 deposit

Central Banks cannot simultaneously control the money supply and target interest rates. Central Banks use the quantity of reserves to peg short term interest rates for interbank loans. Reserve requirements are nowadays just an extension of a central banks toolkit to target interest rates. (federal reserve system it's purposes and functions 2016)

While I wouldn't go as far as to claim that all money is debt you could say most of it is. (money aggregates like M2)

Honestly one more thing should have been told. Currently banks are not required to actually have the money they operate with. The have only a tiny fraction - this means that when one walks in with money to deposit, bank holds this fraction (as a reserve) and lends the majority. And where is the problem? Well, one deposits 100 coins, reserved are 10, than one borrows 90 coins, another one deposits them, than 81 coins are going and bang, we have 1000 coins out of thin air. And in a system where 100% reserve is required, the system contains only 100 initial coins. This means that the bank lends it, the interest belongs to the deposite owner and the bank makes money on provision. So all those weird ways of making money faster than you should are based on the fractioned reserved system. And now required is how much, 3%? Less? I am not sure. And all the further regulations are simply to make it harder to compete with already established banks that can afford dealing with those. Simply require full reserve and all those problems are solved.

Therefore, the risk for the bank is extremly low, because even if a lot of people won't be able to pay their credit back, the bank will still get money from the central bank. Therefore, the bank also gives money to people who are very unlikely to ever pay back their credit, which leads to malinvestments, which causes the collaps of the economy.

There is a simple solution. Make bankers personally liable for their bad investments. If a bank goes under the owner of the bank has to pay out of their own pockets until the last cent they own. If their personal wealth is not enough to cover the losses the bank is left to fail and the state will only reimburse the clients who had their money saved in that bank. This weeds out the irresponsible banks, because now the people who work there have huge stakes in the game. Clients won't lose trust in banks because their savings are guaranteed by the state, rather than a bank. Bail outs are bad because they send the message that if the bank makes bad choices the state is going to save it. It's basically rewarding the behaviors that caused the problem in the first place. This is how it should be anyway. Because if an individual has debts they cannot pay, banks will make you go bankrupt. There is no bail out for individuals, likewise there should be no bail out for banks.

I love Kurzgesagt videos, unfortunately this one is flawed and repeats wide misconceptions. Banks don't lend money that you deposit to generate profits, money is 'created' when you take out a mortgage and pay interest on it. That 'money' (and the interest payable) did not exist previously but now forms part of a debit/credit transaction between commercial and central banks. These new funds generated are added to the economy which is why we have inflation, it's not that things get more expensive it's that there is more 'money' in the system and hence has less spending power.

I'd like to see a Kurzgesagt video on central banks, the origins and structure of debt markets and why we have to pay so much as a society to support it. Keep up the great work by the way!

I think you need to take a deeper philosophical explanation of "what money is" and " how credit is assigned". In of itself money has no value or function except as a medium of exchange. This means that it depends on a consensus of those using that medium as to the relative value of different goods and services in different countries. Obviously this is not fixed but changes over time depending on the market for those goods and services and crucially on the exchange rate between currencies. In turn exchange rates depend on the confidence and stability of the currency which involves balance of payments between exports and imports, politics and national debt. Of late so called "developed" countries have "printed" their way out of debt by "quantative easing" meaning that their currencies now have only notional or virtual values and that their national debts are now astronomic and therefore meaningless. Still with me ? Credit ratings which determine what rates of interest countries have to pay for borrowing money from each other depends on what the true value of money really is. "People keep their money in banks and receive a small amount of interest."

This is the orthodox theory of how banks work. Really the past few decades have proven it to be inaccurate. Ask the Japanese about interest for deposits, then consider the Western countries are headed the same place for the same reasons (politically misguided encouragement of asset inflation followed by fiscal policy meant to avoid a credit crunch that ends up with zombie financial institutions - not alive, but no mechanism to die, either).

Really the banks lend first to anyone they think will repay with interest, and worry about the formality of deposits later. If you go to the bank and ask for a credit card, you can be sure they don't check anything to make sure they have funds available, they issue the card. If the bank arrives in a situation where the level of deposits is insufficient (which is quickly diminishing as legislation relaxes the reserve ratio on many kinds of accounts), it barely even matters since they can borrow deposits from the central banks at no interest. In fact, this is what they've been doing for years, which of course is enormously profitable. You gotta pay them, but they don't have to pay the central bank, and the central bank doesn't even follow the pretense of getting deposits from anywhere, the whole idea is they create money as they deem fit.

It's obvious that the banking system is even more volatile than before. Now the basis is not related to deposits, this is merely a nod to tradition. The banking system now more than ever is a straight confidence game, where the only value of the currency is faith in the ability of the central bank to manage panic. Money really has nothing to do with any kind of value (not even the ability of taxpayers to fund governments) and everything to do with market perceptions.

@Kurz Gesagt - In a Nutshell - I try to start off by saying something nice before I criticize, unfortunately this is the first video on your channel I watched and I have some criticism. Edit: I've now watched almost all your videos and I love your channel!!

First I have to disclaim that I'm speaking about banking in the US, though I understand that it is very similar to the way English and European banks with, with some notable exceptions.

Banks don't lend deposits to other customers, banks create money they lend out of thin air. They then credit the borrowers account. The bank keeps the loan contract as it's asset and creates a liability of equal amount that must be repaid on a schedule. When the loan is repaid it cancels out the liability on the banks books and what the bank is left with is the interest as it's gross profit. The bank they pays salaries, taxes, rent and other expenses and what's left after that is it's net profits. If the customer defaults, the bank must pay the losses from it's capital account.

Banks are required to keep 10% of the money it has on loan in reserves (this is NOT the banks capital account). Customer deposits are desired for banks for this reason. Banks can get the money to meet it's reserve requirements from 3 places.

Customer deposits
Borrow from other banks
The Central bank (the Fed)

Banks pay customers very little in interest, thus is the best way to meet it's reserve requirements. Banks do lend customer deposits, but only to other banks. So banks don't use customer deposits to make money, but save money (which increases the money they make).

A banks constraint on lending is based on how much money it has in it's capital account at the Central Bank.

The more money it has, the more it can lend. If/ when it's capital account reaches zero, it goes bankrupt. This is the "risk" portion of banking.

There is a major problem with banking at the moment:
A bank can give out credits 20 times bigger than their capital. Money, that does not exist, is created.
Then the debtor has to pay back even more money, which essentially does not exist. (10000€ - 11000€ = -1000€) As a result money ist created in form of debts.
This results in inflation and this is the main problem.
Over time the debts overall grow and more and more money is in circulation.
The interest you get by storing your money at a bank only compensates the inflation and doesn´t make you richer...
If nothing changes, one day our financial system will collapse in a huge crash...

The word "bank" in the financial sense is a metaphor for a riverbank.

"Banks" control the "flow" of "currency" (in the same way that a river directs the flow of water currents).

A healthy economy is often referred to as having high "liquidity".

Complete rubbish. Modern banking originated with the goldsmiths creating certificates for the gold people put in their care. They quickly learned that they could loan out more of these certificates than they had gold to back them up. Modern banking was founded on fraud. Today there's no gold, just the paper certificates. Banks don't loan their depositors' money. Every loan is created out of nothing! The deposits act as a limit to the total amount that can be lent, nothing more. When a bank loan is paid back, the principle is actually destroyed, because it came from nothing. The interest is retained as profit after expenses.

It is an unsustainable system, because the banks don't create the interest, just the principle. The interest must be paid back from other debts in circulation or future debts. This leads to a perpetual debt bubble that must keep growing or else the Ponzi scheme collapses. This is what really causes the perpetual inflation (devaluation) of the currency. Today's dollar is just 4% of its value when the Federal Reserve was founded in 1913. Inflation = theft. Eventually the total debt becomes so high, the interest burden collapses the system.

Fucking left wing propaganda video demonizing banks and capitalism without explaining the whole story.

The banks were "giving loans to basically anybody that wanted a house" because the government, under president Jimmy Carter, created regulations that FORCED the banks to give out loans to people the banks already new would not be able to pay them back. Then under president Bill Clinton, the government doubled down on those regulations, forcing the banks to provide even more high risk loans.

The banks new it was all going to collapse eventually so they took steps to attempt to protect themselves. These steps were twisted by the liberally biased media into nothing more than corporate greed. Also around this time, many politicians, like John McCain were warning that the housing bubble was going to burst, and attempted to push legislation to repeal the regulations that forced the banks into giving the high risk loans in the first place. However, left leaning politicians like John Kerry, Nancy Pelosi, Hillary and Bill Clinton, and Al Gore, continued to ignore the warning signs and even adamantly state that there was no danger of a housing market collapse. Not even 3 years later the bubble burst and the great recession took hold.

Then the government decided that rather than backing off the banks and allowing them to fix the issue, they created several "stimulus packages" which was basically just creating dollars that did not exist, and writing huge checks to the banks. They even forced some banks, like J.P. Morgan Chase, to take the money, even though Chase said they did not want it, and paid the money back as soon as they were legally allowed to.

And why did the government decide to force these ridiculous regulations on the banks in the first place? To prevent a practice called "red lining" in which banks used to literally use a red marker, and outline areas on a city map that were generally lower income areas, or areas of high unemployment and crime. The banks new that people from those areas were far less likely to pay back a mortgage, so they were basically denied from the outset, unless they could prove they had the means to pay the loan back (lottery winnings, inheritances, long term employment at a high paying job, etc.)

The problems arose when somebody realized that a lot of minorities tended to live in these red lined areas. Suddenly, rather than it being a slightly unfair business practice, the banks were accused of rampant racism, which of course prompted the left wing lead government to do what they always do. Stick their noses where they don't belong and write laws forcing businesses to take up damaging business practices.

If you have ever heard of the "malaise" of the late 1970s, this was a big part of it. Just another one of Carter's failures as president.

How realistic is a post-scarcity society? I'm not talking about it being in our lifetime, just in general, could a human society like that exist? As a simple way model this, I often think about online video games, specifically MMORPGs: while there is an unlimited supply of gold and items, it still takes time and effort to obtain them, which is why they have 'value' in the game's economy. For post-scarcity society to function at all, we'd need not only a limitless (or at least limitless in practice) supply of any resource, but it would also have to be effortless, otherwise people will place value on the time and effort it takes to produce that resource.

You made a mistake. The term BANCO defines a TABLE in Italian, not a bench. Take a look at Frederic Lane, History of Venice: "The main function of a Venetian banker was not to make loans, but make payments on behalf of its customers. These loans were not transferred by signing the checks, who made a payment appeared in person in front of the banker, sitting behind a desk (the BANCO) on the porch of Rioalto, and the payer orally instructed the banker (THE ONE BEHIND THE DESK) to make a transfer to the account of the person to whom it was intended to pay". IMPORTANT ANNOUNCEMENT: This was a video sponsored by the lovely (and patient!) folks at PSCU, thanks again for the support! What does this mean? It means that we got funding for doing this topic sooner than we would have done otherwise – the sponsor had no influence over the content of the video! This video represents our own research and opinion on the topic. This video is a bonus video, on top of our regular uploads.
The reason I’m posting this here is that we want to be super up front and honest about sponsorships — we do want to make videos that entertain you and that help make the world a little bit more awesome. But it is impossible to sustain ourselves with the youtube channel – we are too many people and the videos take too long to produce. So we will do sponsorships to make this Youtube channel more sustainable from time to time. How is this gonna work: Sponsors can pay us to do certain topics, or to have their project features at the end of the video (like the audible adds lots of STEM channels do). But the scripts will not be approved by a sponsor. Everything we tell you is researched by us. We are in the explaining stuff business, not in the advertisement business (well, ok, you can hire us to produce a video – but it won’t go up on our youtube channel). 
If you have questions or comments please tell us, total transparency is super important for us. And if you want to help us get 100% independent from sponsors, you can support us directly at Patron: http://bit.ly/1NOxZ7p. Our ultimate goal is doing youtube and similar projects full time, for you guys and because it is so much fun. Thank you for reading this far! - Philipp
